awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  CYBORG cells:  Modular integration of synthetic organelles into living cells
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of a larger effort to understand fundamental rules of life, this project aims to make hybrid cells with living and artificial parts in order to ask how cellular organelles function together as modular units. Cells contain diverse organelles that play specific roles and interact with other functional units. By developing hybrids of living cells with synthetic parts (cyborgs), this project provides an innovative approach to understand modularity. Immediate goals are to develop artificial cytoskeletons to allow control of cell shape and organization upon command, offering insights into basic cellular processes. This project also examines societal impacts to inform the team's researchers and to help prepare public presentations to increase broader impacts. This work should spark public discussion on the role of hybrid organisms in society and will examine public concerns of producing something 'unnatural.' Additional impacts include training a highly interdisciplinary research team, with intensive mentoring in each group and across groups. The topic will engage the public and provide opportunity for numerous outreach projects and public events.

How cellular processes can be explained by modularity remains poorly understood, partly because of the lack of tools for manipulating whole organelles. The project focuses on developing two types of artificial cytoskeletons (synCyto) that can be introduced into living cells and controlled experimentally, based on: 1) Spirostomum myonemes and (2) Magnetic particles (Magnetic Robotic Swarms). The prediction is that these will form dynamic assemblages inside of cells that can be controllable experimentally through inputs such as light or magnetic fields to change cell shape and move other organelles. This work provides proof of principle towards developing hybrid cells with multiple synthetic organelles. Such synthetic organelles promise to provide prosthetic function to replace or augment native organelles, and have the potential to confer new and enhanced cellular functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The long term goal of this project was to seek to design and incorporate synthetic organelles into cells, creating “cyborg” cells. Ultimately, this approach may create synthetic modular prosthetic replacements for dysfunctional or missing organelles, with the focus here on the cytoskeleton. We focused on building cyborg cells to understand fundamental rules of nature concerning modularity. Organelles seem to function as modules of cells, and they also consist of modular parts. Building these cyborgs will test the hypothesis that modularity of cellular life is a rule of life and will allow predictions that extend to other organelles. This approach also provides a route to expanding understanding of cellular function more broadly.


We initially focused on developing both fully synthetic, magnetic particle based synthetic cytoskeletons and, in parallel, to develop transplantable biological cytoskeletons based on contractile machinery in the ultrafast unicellular ciliate Spirostomum. We developed a magnetic tweezer based approach that is able to move cargoes around inside living mammalian cells, thereby achieving one of the important functions of the cytoskeleton. We also made significant advances in understanding the mechanism of Spirostomum contraction, which undergoes ultrafast calcium-triggered contraction. Some of these results are summarized in the attached images, which depicts a comic book style summary of our recent paper published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Going forward, these new advances in understanding ultrafast contraction will enable us to implant contractile machinery from this organism into other cell types, potentially imparting new functionality to them.


An additional important part of this project was to examine what is meant by cyborg cells. Creating hybrids of living and synthetic has historically created considerable social concerns and bioethical worries. With our collaborators on this project, we examined the historical context of ‘synthetic’ and ‘artificial’ cells, and used this context to inform our current work, and to guide us in communicating our work broadly. We also developed a public exhibit communicating how cells are imaged and imagined, which is on display at the Marine Biological Laboratory’s library.


Last Modified: 02/15/2024
Modified by: Mary W Elting
